pullRequest.body:
See [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2310725.20and.20.2310728.3A.20L-series/near/422590170) on Zulip.

The main point of this PR is to refactor `LSeries` and friends to use an argument `f : â„• â†’ â„‚` instead of `f : ArithmeticFunction â„‚`. Since I was at it anyway, I also did a few more things:
* Move the L-series stuff out of the `ArithmeticFunction` namespace. Use `LSeries` as a namespace for some of the declarations instead.
* Introduce `LSeries.term f s n`; this denotes the `n`th term in the L-series `LSeries f s`. This is defined to be zero for `n = 0`; otherwise it is the usual `f n / n ^ s`. Provide basic API for it.
* Re-write `LSeries` etc. in terms of `LSeries.term`. Attempt to isolate the meat of the proofs in suitable API lemmas for `LSeries.term`. Add some API (like congruence lemmas).
* Use `s` for the complex variable (in place of `z` or `w`; `s` and `s'` when two are required), following the notational convention in analytic number theory.
* Golf some proofs.
* Add some documentation (and modify existing docstrings to fit the changes).


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @AntoineChambert-Loir, @CBirkbeck : are there still parts of this PR you have yet to look at, or want to discuss further? Or shall I ask for the maintainers to merge it as-is? I personally think it's looking good, and I see @kbuzzard has already given a thumbs-up too.
Yes it all LGTM!

Since Michael is keen to get this merged quickly, and three reviewers (Kevin, Chris and I) have approved these changes, I think we should go ahead.

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8137814169/job/22237095599)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8137814169/job/22237094761)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8137814169/job/22237095416)
Here are some comments on the first part â€“Â more to come later
This looks great to me. Thanks for ploughing through it!
Looks good to me!

```suggestion
 * `LSeries f` is the L-series with a given sequence `f` as its
```

```suggestion
    just the sum of the infinite series if it exists and zero otherwise.
```

I feel that the `IsBigO` version of this lemma, rather than the version with an explicit constant, is in some sense the "right" formulation for general use and hence should be the ones flagged up in the module-level docstring. (Same applies to next lemma.) But that's just my opinion, I'm happy to defer to you if you prefer it this way.
I have changed the docstring to refer to the `IsBigO` versions.

```suggestion
We define the `n`th term evaluated at a complex number `s` of the L-series associated
```
This is just `funext (term_def f s)`, isn't it? So I am not sure we need it as a separate lemma.
It is sometimes convenient for rewriting (so far it is used once, so maybe not so important, but I don't think it hurts to have it).
Why not â€œrw [funext term_def]â€?
`funext term_def` does not type-check. `funext (term_def 0 s)` works (in `LSeriesSummable_zero`), so I'll remove `term_def'` (but keep `term_def`).
I think putting the attribute `@[simps]` on `term` will generate this automatically, won't it?
`@[simps]` only works on structures. `@[simp]` does not seem to give something that does what `term_def'` does.
`term_of_ne_zero`? Otherwise it sounds like you're showing `term s f n â‰  0`.
OK (same for `_pos`).

We probably don't want this as well as the previous lemma. See remarks in Library Style Guidelines (https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#normal-forms) which suggest that `n â‰  0` in hypotheses is preferred.
Right -- the philosophy is that dot notation gives us `term_ne_zero hn.ne' f s` as a proof, so we don't need this variant.

The thing is that depending on the situation, we may either have `n â‰  0` or `0 < n` available, and it is convenient to have both variants. (The first one is used 6 times, the second one three times.)
The point is that if `h : 0 < n` is available, then `n â‰  0` is trivially available as `h.ne'`, so it's `n â‰  0` in hypotheses and `0 < n` in conclusions.
True; I wasn't thinking of that. Removed `term_of_pos` now.
Might be best to put the argument `h` first here
OK.

```suggestion
  Â· rw [if_neg hn, term_ne_zero hn, norm_div, norm_natCast_cpow_of_pos <| Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hn]
```

```suggestion
  rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with hn | hn <;> simp [hn, h]
```
The `simp only`s are likely slightly faster, but it shouldn't make a big difference here.

```suggestion
  Â· rfl
```

```suggestion
 * `LSeriesSummable f s` indicates that the L-series of `f` converges at `s : â„‚`.
```

```suggestion
  split
```
Given that we seem to have lost Lean 3 `split` and now have to use `constructor` to split `And` goals, we may as well use the Lean 4 `split` (which does something different, i.e. it does this) whenever we can.
I did not manage to name the hyptheses with `split`, but here it is not necessary.

```suggestion
  simp only [norm_term_eq]
  split
  Â· simp
  Â· gcongr
    norm_cast
    omega
```
Maybe this just shows I'm lazier than you? My proof takes 0.06 seconds to run, yours 0.04, so there's another argument for yours.

```
  simp only [norm_term_eq]
  split
  next => rfl
  next hn => gcongr; exact Nat.one_le_cast.mpr <| Nat.one_le_iff_ne_zero.mpr hn
```
is still slightly slower, but not by that much.

```suggestion
/-- The value of the L-series of the sequence `f` at the point `s` (if it converges absolutely there). -/
```

```suggestion
/-- `LSeriesSummable f s` indicates that the L-series of `f` converges absolutely at `s`. -/
```

This really is a situation where there are examples in nature where series converge but not absolutely, right? So probably we should be unambiguous here. Or does the paper literature use "converges" to mean "converges absolutely" here?
I think "convergence" in the literature means conditional convergence. But in Mathlib, we basically only have absolute convergence of series...

I'm not actually sure what is linguistically correct here. If we have an infinite sum sum_n a_n such that sum |a_n| converges to x and sum a_n converges to y, can one summarise this situation by saying that "the sum converges (absolutely) to y"? If "converges (absolutely) to y" is ambiguous (it's clearly confusing me, at least!) then maybe we want to avoid this phrase?
I'm re-wording this.

```suggestion
/-- The `LSeries` with all coefficients `1` converges at `s` if and only if `re s > 1`. -/
```

```suggestion
  Â· simp only [indicator_of_mem hn, norm_term_eq]
    simp only [show n â‰  0 from hn, â†“reduceIte, Pi.one_apply, norm_one, ofReal_re]
```
Just demonstrating a golfy hack in case you think it's worth it!

Not a comment on this PR, but a general comment about this proof: I've heard people express concern about proofs of the form `convert foo ; <complex tactics>` because they're susceptible to hard-to-fix breakage if definitions are refactored.
I have replaced `norm_num` by a `simp only` call (which I hope does not count as "complex").

```suggestion
  âŸ¨fun H â†¦ H.of_re_le_re h.le, fun H â†¦ H.of_re_le_re h.symm.leâŸ©
```
OK.
would it be interesting to make arguments `s` and `f` implicit?

It wouldn't make a difference, as in all use cases the arguments are inferred.
I'm not sure what the preferred style is in such a case.
I think implicitizing `f` and `s` is probably a bad idea, because they can't be inferred from any other arguments, so making them implicit would be painful when calling the lemma directly.
if it converges absolutely, and 0 otherwise.
OK.
The proof gives an upper bound that has some uniformity in `s`
The statement is for a fixed `s`. Of course, we obtain the same bound for all `s'` with `re s' â‰¥ re s` from this.
The proof gives a uniform summability that will be important to prove that the LSeries is holomorphic in s

We don't actually need that (I have a proof of the fact that the L-series is (complex) differentiable on its half-plane of absolute convergence via `hasDerivAt_tsum_of_isPreconnected`).

What might be interesting eventually is to also consider conditional convergence. Then it is likely to become relevant for proving that the function is holomorphic on the half-plane of conditional convergence. But this is for future work.
Yes, and it will be time, then, to write the lemmas that are necessary.
The proof is more delicate, IIRC, involving partial summation, so this will require some work. Any volunteers :smile: ?

I vote that we leave issues of conditional convergence for later work â€“Â I think such statements would be hard to even formulate in Mathlib as of now, since in mathlib convergence of sums is defined to mean unconditional convergence.

We now have the Abel Limit Theorem, which talks about conditional convergence, but so far, it needs to be written as `Tendsto (fun n => (range n).sum f) a` (with `open Filter Finset`). This is workable, but a dedicated API would be nice.

Slight generalizations could be useful: if the coefficients do not go to 0, `re s > 1` is necessary ; 
if they are bounded, `re s > 1` is sufficient.

If you take the indicator function of the subset of `k`th powers as `f`, then the L-series converges for `re s > 1/k`, but the coefficients do not go to zero. The second statement is there (`LSeriesSummable_of_bounded_of_one_lt_re`).
you're perfectly right, the first (correct) lemma would just say that `re s > 0` is necessary, and it's not enough.

Below, you have to replicate a lot of stuff that says that what applies to a LSeries comes from the input function. 
In some sense, having a `LSeries` type and a map `(â„• â†’ â„‚) â†’ LSeries`  (actually a `LinearMap`), and various `LSeries.summable L s`, etc. which would just take a `LSeries` Lâ€¦
Wouldn't this `LSeries` type essentially be the same as `ArithmeticFunction â„‚`? Which is what I think the consensus was to move away from. Or what would your definition of `LSeries` be?

Isn't it easier to define it by the infimum of sigma that `term f n n^(-sigma)` converges to 0, or is bounded, or even by the corresponding lim sup property . Compare with [FormalMultilinearSeries.radius](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.radius)

It is not that simple; compare my comment on the indicator function of `k`th powers.
The convergence behavior of Dirichlet series is much more subtle than that of power series. E.g., there can be a difference of up to `1` between the abscissa of conditional convergence and that of absolute convergence.
indeed, so forget about my remark.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(NumberTheory/LSeries/*): change type of argument to `â„• â†’ â„‚`, add `LSeries.term` + API etc.
